content.description: 3 pitches, two of real climbing, crux is on a lichen filled groove on P2.  P1 is full of exfoliating rock, and could be very spicy due to loose footing.  With some more traffic it could clean up well.  A brush wouldn't be the worst thing to happen to the route.
content.protection: 3 bolts P1, 2 bolts P2, all in great shape.  P3 rally some easy 5th slab to the anchors with no pro.
content.location:
Rap down from the top, a rope stretching 200' (knots in the ends!) to the first anchors over the crux bit, then two more raps to a set of bolts at the end of the 4th class slab.

Option two: cut over along the trail at some point before the summit and meander along steep slab until you find the starting bolts.

climbs.name: Teardrop
climbs.fa: M. Dumic, J. Butkins, T. Cook (1976)

content.description:
P1 Runout right below the bolts for belay.

P2 Much steeper and crux is between 1st and 2nd bolt.
content.protection: Bring light rack and nuts that can be converted to rivet hangers because some bolts are absent a hanger.
content.location:
Starts right as the treeline levels out coming down out of the arch bowl from the start of High Anxiety.

Or from the bottom of Indian lookout, traverse down to climber's right until just before the treeline start going up. Can be confused with Stainless Steel if far enough west.

climbs.name: Indian Lookout
climbs.fa: Gerald Laws, Mike Fischesser, Jerry Laws, and John Davis (1973)

content.description: Runout low angle from the treeline until a horizontal crack marks the change in grade.
content.protection: LIght rack of nuts and cams. Go light and bring only tricams. 4 bolts to top if starting from the bolted belay on the right side.
content.location: Easternmost route on the North face and also the only decent rap station from top.

content.description: This route follows the right-facing corner up between the prominent water grooves. Start is easy to find, just follow the tree-line to top of it's arch. The crux is as the dihedral turns to more of a roof before peetering out.  This is definitely a steeper route compared to most at Stone mountain.
content.protection: Light rack and a few finger to hand cams. Double bolts are after the crux and can be used to make a hanging belay for a short 1st pitch.
content.location:
The easternmost route of the westside of the North Face. Start is the prominent corner between the water grooves at the top of the treeline arch.

Top is also easy to find, as there water stains converging into the bowl that marks the second pitch.

Descend by walking of west down the Loop trail back to the treeline or rap from the rings above Indian Lookout (farthest east route).
